title: Demo
content:
const cloneRunCode = `# Clone the repository git clone https://github.com/jermeyyy/seal.git cd seal # Run the Android demo app ./gradlew :composeApp:installDebug # Run on iOS (macOS only) open iosApp/iosApp.xcodeproj` const demoAppCode = `// The demo app showcases CT verification in action val client = HttpClient(OkHttp) { install(CertificateTransparency) { // Verify all hosts + // Log results logger = { host, result -> println( ) } } } // Make a request and see CT results in the logs val response = client.get( Status: \${response.status} CT verification passed! >Running the Demo

Prerequisites

  • JDK 17+ and Android SDK
  • Android Studio or IntelliJ IDEA
  • For iOS: macOS with Xcode installed

Clone and Run

Code Example from Demo

Main CT Configuration

title: Getting Started
content:
>Installation

Version Catalog Configuration

Add the Seal dependencies to your Gradle version catalog:

Gradle Dependencies

Configure module dependencies in your KMP project />

Quick Start with OkHttp

For Android projects using OkHttp, add the CT network interceptor:

Quick Start with Ktor

For Kotlin Multiplatform projects using Ktor, install the CT plugin:

Platform Requirements

Platform Minimum Version HTTP Client
Android API 21+ OkHttp / Ktor (OkHttp engine)
iOS iOS 13+ Ktor (Darwin engine)

Available Modules

Module Description
seal-core Core CT verification logic, models, log list parsing, and policies
seal-android Android-specific: OkHttp interceptor, Conscrypt SCT extraction
seal-ios iOS-specific: SecTrust integration, Darwin networking support
seal-ktor Ktor plugin for multiplatform CT verification

Next Steps

Now that you have basic CT verification running, explore more:

  • OkHttp Integration — Full guide for Android OkHttp setup
  • Ktor Integration — Multiplatform Ktor plugin guide
  • Custom Policies — Chrome and Apple CT policies
  • Configuration — All available configuration options

title: Configuration
content:
>Full Configuration Example

Here />

Host Patterns

Control which hosts undergo CT verification using inclusion and exclusion operators:

Pattern Description Example
+ Include all subdomains Matches www.example.com, api.example.com
+ Include specific host Matches only www.example.com
- >CT Policy

Set the Certificate Transparency policy to use for verification:

  • ChromeCtPolicy() — Default. Uses Google Chrome s CT requirements.

Failure Modes

Setting Behavior Use Case
failOnError = false Log failure, allow request (fail-open) Initial deployment, monitoring
failOnError = true Throw exception, block request (fail-closed) Strict enforcement, security-critical apps

Log List Configuration

Seal fetches the list of trusted CT logs to verify SCTs against. You can configure the source and caching:

  • logListUrl — URL to fetch the CT log list from. Defaults to Google >Next Steps
    • OkHttp Integration — Apply configuration with OkHttp
    • Ktor Integration — Apply configuration with Ktor

title: Custom Policies
content:
>What is a CT Policy?

A CT Policy defines the rules for determining whether a certificate has sufficient Certificate Transparency coverage. Different vendors (Google, Apple) have different requirements for how many SCTs (Signed Certificate Timestamps) a certificate needs and from which logs they must come.

Chrome CT Policy

The Chrome CT Policy is the default policy used by Seal. It mirrors the requirements that Google Chrome uses for CT enforcement:

  • Requires SCTs from multiple independent CT logs
  • SCTs must come from logs that are currently trusted
  • Number of required SCTs depends on certificate lifetime
  • At least one SCT must be from a Google-operated log and one from a non-Google log

Apple CT Policy

The Apple CT Policy follows Apple >Using Policies Policy Comparison
Feature Chrome Policy Apple Policy
Default in Seal Yes No
Log diversity Google + non-Google Apple requirements
Lifetime-based SCT count Yes Yes

Next Steps

  • Configuration Reference — All available options
  • OkHttp Integration — Apply policies with OkHttp

title: Ok Http
content:
>Basic Setup

Add the seal-android dependency and create an OkHttp client with the CT interceptor:

Network vs Application Interceptor

Seal must be added as a network interceptor, not an application interceptor. Network interceptors have access to the TLS connection, which is required to extract SCTs (Signed Certificate Timestamps) from the TLS handshake.

Configuration DSL

The interceptor builder supports a rich DSL for configuring host patterns, error handling, and logging:

Host Inclusion & Exclusion

Control which hosts are verified using inclusion and exclusion patterns:

  • + — Include all subdomains of google.com
  • + — Include a specific host
  • - — Exclude a specific host
  • Exclusions take precedence over inclusions
  • If no inclusions are specified, all hosts are included by default

Error Handling

Seal supports two failure modes:

  • Fail-open (default): failOnError = false — CT verification failures are logged but don >Next Steps
    • Ktor Integration — For multiplatform HTTP clients
    • Custom Policies — Chrome vs Apple CT policies

title: i O S
content:
>How CT Works on iOS

On iOS, Certificate Transparency verification leverages the platform s built-in CT support

  • Works with URLSession-based networking (Ktor Darwin engine)

    • Ktor Darwin Engine Setup

    The recommended way to use Seal on iOS is through the Ktor Darwin engine:

    Platform Considerations

    • Minimum iOS version: iOS 13+ is required for full SecTrust CT support
    • App Transport Security: ATS provides baseline security. Seal adds explicit CT verification on top of ATS.
    • Background networking: CT verification works with background URLSession tasks.

    Next Steps

    • Ktor Integration — Full multiplatform Ktor guide
    • Configuration Reference — All available options

title: Home
content:
/> View on GitHub {/* Overview */}

Overview

Seal is a Certificate Transparency (CT) verification library for Kotlin Multiplatform. It enforces CT compliance on HTTPS connections, ensuring that TLS certificates are logged in public transparency logs. Seal supports Android and iOS, with integrations for both OkHttp and Ktor HTTP clients.

{/* Why Seal */}

Show Me The Code!

  • OkHttp Integration — Full OkHttp interceptor guide
  • Ktor Integration — Multiplatform Ktor plugin guide

  • Demo Application — See Seal in action
